Summary: I saw what appeared to be a twinkling star about 45 degrees above the horizon at approximately NNW.
trends: There have been 17 other sightings in Huntsville
There were no other sightings in Huntsville on or around May 25th 2009
divs: Sighting DetailsI was leaving a friend's house at about 9:20 in the evening and we paused to take in the sky as it had been raining earlier and now the stars were shining. As I looked with my friends ( a man and his wife) I was showing them the big Dipper and noticed that there was a "star" that was twinkling. I remarked that i thought that was odd, because none of the other visible stare were twinkling. I told my friends I would take a look with my binoculars when I got home. My house was a ten minute drive from their place and when I got home I got my binoculars out and took a quick look at this "star". I was not able to resolve it into any shape, but it was red, green, and white and appeared to oscillate between those colors. At this point i knew it was not a star. I hurried into the house to get my telescope because the object was slowly drifting to the horizon. My telescope is a Questar 3.5 and I used a 16mm occular which provided 81 power magnification and about a 1 arc second resolution. I found the object and attempted to focus but was not able to image anything other than a point of light that varied between red, green and white. Because of where I had my focus set, in relationship to other nearby stars, I had the impression that this object was really far away (outside the atmosphere). The light was fairly bright for the distance. I would guess a magnitude 3. I watched the object for about 10 minutes before it went below the horizon. This was not a plane, blimp, weather balloon or any conventional flying object. I am a retired army officer with an extensive background in missiles and air defense.
